title: Are newer generations really more sensitive than older generations? Is the term 'Generation Snowflake' appropriate? - Quora

response.answer_text: Considering some members of the older generations got dangerously offended when they saw a little black girl entering an all-whites school, and sent death threats to the family and threatened to kill her, no, I’d say that younger generations are not more offended than older generations. You remember Ellen coming out in the 90’s, and the horrible backlash it caused for something as simple as not liking men, sexually? Don’t look at those folks and tell me they’re not “snowflakes”. You have to look at what they’re getting offended by. And yes, some people do take their outrage too far. We know there’s nothing wrong with being gay. We know women should be considered equal, in terms of their rights. We know there is no reason for for blacks to be treated differently because of the color of their skin, by police and businesses. So when we see people advocating for things counter to these points of views, people get pissed off! These aren’t things you can argue about! These are basic facts. Hell, look at the present so-called Commander-in-Chief, and all the mock outrage he spits out at people kneeling during football games, when the true source of his outrage against the NFL stems from a business deal he made during the 80’s. It’s not even genuine, he’s just playing his followers like a fiddle! Some of the members of the older generation get offended at things they’re not even really offended by, they just want to fight! So no, the younger generation doesn’t have an exclusive at taking offense. In fact, the older generation, and generations before them, seem to get offended at the most minute, trivial of things. Like a little black girl’s skin color. I’ll be honest, I don’t know how the hell we beat Hitler during WWII sometimes, or helped beat him rather, with as weenie as some of these guys were. Yes, there were a lot of fine, upstanding patriotic soldiers, but don’t forget that many of these men were the same men who came to lynch black soldiers and gouge out their eyes, once they had returned from their tours of duty. They were the same men who abandoned their black compatriots once back on home soil, because the ‘standard norm’ didn’t allow for them to be nice to them. They turned their backs on them, and ignored the friendships they had forged. Sometimes they ignored them. Other times, they killed them. Again, it wasn’t 100%. It wasn’t all of them! It may not even have been more than 45%! But it was a large amount. No one can deny that. Many of those Ku Klux Klan members were former soldiers, in all likelihood. Because that’s what you did in the 40’s and 50’s, if you lived in certain places, and were vulnerable to certain influences. I’ll never forget the interviews given by some members of supremacist groups in documentaries like the ones on PBS, in archival footage, where individuals go on and on about how blacks can’t be allowed in the neighborhood because they’ll bring down the value, and how offensive it is that they’re living so close to white people, and yet they look like the biggest trash imaginable! It’s not the black people those neighborhoods had to worry about, it was you!!! How’s that for being offended? Over something as trivial as skin color. And of course, now we have the ultimate Snowflake in power, a man who gets offended if the media doesn’t worship him, like a god. Sorry, man, you’re not a god. And if you do something stupid, the media has a duty to report on it. It’s nothing to take offense at. *sneer*

Younger generations are more sensitive to getting their feelings hurt and extrapolate that narcissistic sensitivity to the feelings of others creating a faux-sensitivity towards others as well as a greater hypocrisy within their belief systems. Texting is an example of their insensitive treatment of other humans. Tattooing and body piercings are examples of their narcissistic insensitivity to the environment. Going to the tattoo parlor consumes fuel and sterilization of the equipment consumes energy. Gold and silver for body jewelry are mined. Trees and grasslands replaced by tattoo parlor parking lots. Medical resources consumed on tattoo and piercing related problems such as infection. So ‘Generation Snowflake’ is a fitting, appropriate term.

Everyone is overly sensitive about something. There are overly sensitive, thin skinned people in every group and every generation. To say that one is more sensitive than the other, especially since generations are simply made up terms by the powers to further divide the people.

No. In fact, the older generation is overly sensitive about people of different races drinking from the same water fountain as them. The older generation are the ones who demand to see a manager when their expired coupons get denied.
